prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The targeted high-mass hot cores have line widths on the order of a few km/s, namely 5 km/s for G327.3-0.6 (Gibb et al. 2000), 6 km/s for NGC 6334 I(N) (Brogan et al. 2009) and 9 km/s for G29.96-0.02 (Beltran et al. 2011). The requested spectral resolution of around 0.7 km/s allows for the lines to be resolved and the identification of any possible blending. This value also balances the loss of bandwidth, thus maximizing the number of obtained lines. Spectral averaging is included to reduce the data rate.

The targeted high-mass hot cores are 0.02 pc in diameter (e.g., Fig. 2 in Bisschop et al. 2007). At an average distance of our sources of 3 kpc, this corresponds to an angular diameter of 1.5-2''. Therefore, an angular resolution of 0.5'' is requested in order to spatially resolve the emitting regions of complex organic molecules, allowing a consistent comparison between the species. The strongest emitting molecules can be mapped for the first time within the hot cores themselves. The recoverable scale of 4'' should be 2 times larger than the size of the targeted hot cores, allowing us to recover the bulk of the emission from all complex organic transitions.

According to our predicted spectrum, for a 2'' source size (the characteristic size of the targeted high-mass hot cores) with a characteristic column density of methanol gas of 10^{18} cm^{-2} and an abundance of 1-propanol at 0.01 of that of methanol (based on the ROSINA measurement), the weakest line peaks around 70 mJy/beam in a 2'' beam. A S/N of at least 7 is required for a robust detection in a 2'' mask (as done in, e.g., Fayolle et al. 2015). This implies that a sensitivity of 10 mJy is required for a 2'' beam. The requested beam size is 0.5'' (in order to image the stronger lines), thus the requested sensitivity is given by 10mJy*sqrt((0.5''/2'')^{2})=2.5 mJy/beam.

The proposed observations only marginally exceed the data rate - only by 0.21 MB/s. At least three lines per species are necessary for a robust detection. Sufficient spectral resolution and bandwidth are necessary in order to detect the minimal number of lines and resolve them, thereby achieving the goals of this proposal. Spectral averaging by 2 is applied. A higher level of averaging results in an unacceptably low spectral resolution for the line widths of high-mass hot cores (e.g., as low as 5 km/s for G327.3-0.6, Gibb et al. 2000).

The targeted high-mass hot cores have line widths on the order of a few km/s, namely 5 km/s for G327.3-0.6 (Gibb et al. 2000), 6 km/s for NGC 6334 I(N) (Brogan et al. 2009) and 9 km/s for G29.96-0.02 (Beltran et al. 2011). The strongest emitting molecules can be mapped for the first time within the hot cores themselves. The recoverable scale of 4'' should be 2 times larger than the size of the targeted hot cores, allowing us to recover the entire emission from all complex organic transitions.

Sufficient spectral resolution and bandwidth are necessary in order to detect the minimal number of lines and resolve them, thereby achieving the goals of this proposal. A higher level of averaging results in an unacceptably low spectral resolution for the line widths of high-mass hot cores (e.g., as low as 5 km/s for G327.3-0.6, Gibb et al. 2000).

The requested spectral resolution of around 0.7 km/s allows for the lines to be resolved and the identification of any possible blending. This value also balances the loss of bandwidth, thus maximizing the number of obtained lines. Spectral averaging is included to reduce the data rate.

The targeted high-mass hot cores are 0.02 pc in diameter (e.g., Fig. 2 in Bisschop et al. 2007). At an average distance of our sources of 3 kpc, this corresponds to an angular diameter of 1.5-2''. Therefore, an angular resolution of 0.5'' is requested in order to spatially resolve the emitting regions of complex organic molecules, allowing a consistent comparison between the species. The strongest emitting molecules can be mapped for the first time within the hot cores themselves. The recoverable scale of 4'' should be 2 times larger than the size of the targeted hot cores, allowing us to recover the bulk of the emission from all complex organic transitions.

According to our predicted spectrum, for a 2'' source size (the characteristic size of the targeted high-mass hot cores) with a characteristic column density of methanol gas of 10^{18} cm^{-2} and an abundance of 1-propanol at 0.01 of that of methanol (based on the ROSINA measurement), the weakest line peaks around 70 mJy/beam in a 2'' beam. The proposed observations only marginally exceed the data rate - only by 0.21 MB/s. At least three lines per species are necessary for a robust detection. Sufficient spectral resolution and bandwidth are necessary in order to detect the minimal number of lines and resolve them, thereby achieving the goals of this proposal. Spectral averaging by 2 is applied. A higher level of averaging results in an unacceptably low spectral resolution for the line widths of high-mass hot cores (e.g., as low as 5 km/s for G327.3-0.6, Gibb et al. 2000).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Comets carry the most primitive volatiles of the natal protoplanetary disk that evolved into our modern-day Solar System. The immediate objective of this proposal is to test whether complex organic molecules found in cometary comae and those observed in distant star-forming systems share a common, prestellar origin. Sequences of molecules in two hierarchical chemical families, namely primary alcohols (R-OH) and cyanides (R-CN), towards three high-mass hot cores (G327.3-0.6, NGC 6334 I(N), G29.96-0.02) are to be observed. These sources are the brightest and chemically richest regions of star-forming systems. These observations are complementary to the newest data arriving from the ROSINA instrument aboard Rosetta. ALMA's high sensitivity is necessary in order to detect the weakest lines and to probe deeply for trace species, such as 1-propanol, which has not been detected outside of our Solar System. This necessity also holds for vinyl alcohol and n-propyl cyanide, which have only been observed towards the galactic center. By observing families, these data provide constrains on our state-of-the-art chemical models of complex organic chemistry.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Physics, Bern, University of
Institute of Physics, Bern, University of
